story:
PROJECT DESCRIPTION

My name is Victoria-Idongesit Udondian. I am a multi-media artist from Nigeria and a non-alien immigrant living in New York City. I graduated with an MFA in Visual Arts from Columbia University in May 2016.

With the cold wind of intolerance, authoritarianism, and nationalism blowing across America and Europe, I feel compelled to respond to notions of border security and immigration. As a Nigerian artist, I am often frustrated trying to gain access to the world—which frequently involves going through a rigorous visa application process.

“The Republic of Unknown Territory” is a multimedia installation/performance project that interrogates the nature of borders, immigration, and privilege by simulating and re-contextualizing the experience of obtaining a visa at a customs office.

In order to recreate the tedium and frustration of the process, “The Republic of Unknown Territory” requires patrons to fill out an adapted version of the Nigerian U.S. visa application form—with deeply intimate questions, ranging from one’s sexuality to income—in order to gain access to the art exhibit and the Republic. While performing as a customs officer, I will grant approvals according to my own subjective whims. This reversal of roles allows me to reconfigure the power dynamics of colonialism within the confines of the gallery space.

“The Republic of Unknown Territory” also externalizes migration through absence: flooding the gallery is hundreds of disembodied shoes, floating hijabs, used clothes, spilling out of suitcases and sculptures of body parts. I will construct these “life casts” with the help of immigrant groups, alluding to the anonymity of countless migrants passing through countries to better their lives while also referencing the many refugees who do not survive the journey. Both the sculptures and stories (video and sound) become documents and artifacts of The Republic of Unknown Territory.

DEVELOPMENT

Currently, I am developing “The Republic of Unknown Territory” as a summer Artist in Residence at A.I.R. Gallery located on Governors Island, New York. During this time, I will expand on the project by inviting immigrants to share their stories with me. These stories and video documentation will be edited into video and sound installation.

This part of the project seeks to foreground the roles and positive contributions of immigrants to their adopted lands. At a time when immigrants are vilified and nationalistic biases increasingly divide developed nations, this project asks us to consider the global migration of refugees and questions the state of society without the contributions of immigrant populations.

Part of the collected stories (in process) will be on view on Governors Island from July 21st to August 5th. Opening reception will be held on July 29th. The final performance/ exhibition will take place in the fall of 2017.

WHY I NEED YOUR HELP

A.I.R. Gallery has generously provided free studio and exhibition space, but cannot offer a production budget. In order to realize this project, I need your help to raise $15,245. The project budget includes:

All funds will be used to produce the exhibit, which can be broken down into three main elements: 

  • The performance
  • The disembodied sculptures and installation
  • The video and sound elements

CAMPAIGN

By backing my Indiegogo campaign, you will make production of this exhibit possible. No amount is too small! If you can't contribute, please consider sharing this campaign on your social media networks. The more we get the word out, the more likely it is that I will actualize this important project. And by supporting me, you will become a citizen of The Republic of Unknown Territory with VIP access to the exhibit!

CONTEXT

With the Trump Presidency and the recent travel ban on Muslim refugees and nationals, much outrage has been focused on how legal visa and green card holders are being denied access into the United States. But well before Trump’s ban, travel for many people around the world has involved extraordinary patience and determination while dealing with a cryptic and mystifying bureaucratic system.

By confronting viewers with an extensive and haphazard application process, American audiences will be able to experience the humiliating, illogical hurdles one must overcome to receive something as simple as a tourist visa to gain entry into the United States.

In the process of (some) patrons being denied entry, the American paradigm of “freedom of movement” is reversed. For many, this might be the first time they have ever applied for a visa and, through the exhibition, they will witness firsthand the extreme measures individuals must take to cross borders.

ARTIST BIO

My name is Victoria-Idongesit Udondian. I am a multi-disciplinary artist from Nigeria and a non-alien immigrant living in New York. For the past 10 years, I have created work that questions notions of cultural identity and post-colonial positions in relation to my experiences.

I received a BA in Painting from the University of Uyo, Nigeria in 2004. In 2013, I won the Most Outstanding Production Award at the National Arts Competition in Lagos. In 2016, I received an MFA in Visual Arts from Columbia University.

My works have been exhibited internationally at the Fisher Landau Center for Art, New York; Historic Columbia Museum, South Carolina; Rush Arts Gallery, New York; Flux Art fair, New York; Judith Charles Gallery, New York; Art 14 London Art Fair, UK; Whitworth Art Gallery, University of Manchester, UK; and Centre for Contemporary Arts, Nigeria.

My artist residencies include: Skowhegan School of Painting & Sculpture; Fine Arts Work Center, Provincetown, MA; Villa Strauli, Winthethur, Switzerland; Islington Mill, Salford, Manchester; Fondazione di Venezia, Venice, Italy; Bag Factory Artist Studios, Johannesburg, South Africa.

"The Republic of Unknown Territory" is an important project for me based on my immigration struggles as a Nigerian. I look forward to your support in creating this context where our collective stories can be shared while also questioning the notions of border control and immigration. You can follow me on Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram, and visit my website to find out more about my work.

STRETCH GOALS

The current campaign budget is the bare-minimum required to carry out this project. If I'm fortunate enough to receive additional money, the extra funds will go towards:

  • Full colour catalogue printing of "The Republic of Unknown Territory" ($2000)
  • Website development ($1000)
  • Tablets for visa e-applications (5 x $200 = $1000)

story:
Bonjour,

Je sollicite aujourd'hui votre soutien.

Après 15 ans de métier dans le spectacle, l'opéra, le cinéma, l'événementiel, en qualité de technicienne maquilleuse artistique, perruquière, peintre décoratrice, je me consacre aujourd'hui à mon art qui est la peinture sur toiles et murales que je pratique depuis 25 ans, et le body painting, que je pratique depuis 16 ans.                                                                                                           Jusqu'à aujourd'hui, j'ai toujours autofinancé mes expositions, salons, performances, communication, matériel, loyers d'atelier. Aujourd'hui, afin que mes projets artistiques grandissent, et pour que je puisse créer et accueillir les personnes dans de bonnes conditions dès 2017, je sollicite votre aide.

Mes activités artistiques sont :                                          

"Les Fées Mères"  www.lesfeesmeres.net  

- Body painting, belly painting, photographie pour la future maman et sa famille.

- Ateliers de body painting, belly painting, face painting en famille. Ses ateliers permettent notamment d'accepter l'arriver du 2 ème enfant par l'ainé ou d'impliquer d'avantage papa dans la grossesse.                                   

- Communication avec le bébé et communication familiale, moment de détente et de bien-être, beauté, valorisation du corps.                                                                                   

- Reportages TV (les maternelles, journal du soir M6) ,radio (France Bleu), web (magic mamans, ma grossesse à Paris), magazines (9 mois, Parents,bébé Nature),salon Baby et évènement Corolles.

 

"AX.LL Soûl Painting"  www.ax-ll.fr                                                                                                               

- Body painting et photographie pour tous                                                                

- Peinture sur toiles et murales personnalisées  , incrustation de  pigment cristal et autres pierres semi précieuses                                                                        

- Peintures intuitives, connaissance de soi, bien-être, soin, zen, énergisantes, apaisantes.

- Ateliers thérapeutiques encadrés par une psychologue et moi-même, pour les personnes dites " psychotiques ou autistes ou......"

- Salon des thérapies/consciences/intuitions, salon Bien être, salon zen

 

La communication est importante pour mes 2 projets artistiques.                                                                  Seule, en rajoutant les moments de création, je me retrouve avec une communication au ralenti par faute de temps et de savoir faire dans ce domaine. Ainsi, j'aimerais employer un community manager, un professionnel , pour booster ma communication, une personne pouvant me trouver des galeries, de nouveaux clients et contacts, faire connaitre mes activités.

Le lieu                                                                                                                                                                                  Je suis actuellement en résidence artistique, cette résidence se termine fin mars, je recherche un lieu pour 2017, spacieux, lumineux , zen et fixe, pour créer mes toiles (certaines font 3m/4 m) et accueillir futures mamans, familles, personnes désirant un body painting dans une ambiance sereine, lumineuse.

 

"Au-delà de l'artistique le bien-être", 

Ma peinture est un lien entre les sociétés ancestrales,tribales et notre société moderne, 

participe à l'éveil collectif,

nous reconnecte à nous-mêmes,  à l'énergie, à la source

énergise les lieux , les pacifie.

 

Le budget nécessaire est de  20000 euros

Community Manager stagiaire 3 ème années :  520€ x 6 mois = 3120€

Atelier de 40 à 60 M2 à Paris ou région Paris ouest :                                                                                

Frais d'agence: 3500€                                                                                                                                      

dépôt de garantie : 3000€                                                                                                                                 

loyer pour les 6 premiers mois :   8400€                                                                                                  

travaux  / Aménagement/ Châssis XXL: 2000€   

                                                                                                                                

Et n'oubliez pas que l'aide peut se faire de différentes manières : passer le mot et faire de la publicité autour de mon projet est aussi une manière de me soutenir .

Si toutefois la cagnotte est en dessous de l'objectif , l'argent récolté servira pour la communication , les frais d'agence ...Si comme je le souhaite, elle atteint son objectif, je serais ravie de créer un lieu et une communication digne de votre confiance , et de vous accueillir dans un lieu artistique et zen.

Je vous remercie pour votre lecture.

Artistiquement vôtre.

Alexandra Berthomé alias AX.LL

story:
Best Mural in Maine, right here in Hallowell.

Let's be honest, Chris, our mural artist, is becoming a hot commodity in the art world, He is sought after to create murals in cities around Maine—and indeed he has two in the works destined for Washington D.C.  It's high time we got Chris to apply his art skills to tell our story for a mural here in our river city.  He's local after all.

 

This project has been evolving for more than a year.  It started just as a chat between the two Chris's of the project.  Hallowell has a rich and important history in the evolution of our state of Maine.  Chris is painting this 950 square foot mural so we can celebrate our history and highlight our present and future townlie endeavors—including ships from the age of sail, famous Hallowell granite sculptures, early settlers, native peoples, LGBTQ community, sanctuary city, arts and music and more, more, more.

It's a simple equation...

Chris Vallee has a wall.  Chris Cart has the mural brushes.  And we all wanted a mural to tell the Hallowell story.  Add it all up and the solution is simple.  Let's do a glorious mural. 

Mural artists just can't resist the temptation of bare walls. 

Officially, both the city's Historic Hallowell and Arts & Cultural committees have given enthusiastic letters of support, as well as Vision Hallowell, our new city's 501 (c)(3).  And the Maine Arts Commission awarded us a grant to help get the mural project started.

"Chris paints in the great mural tradition of Rivera, Benton and Mucha, Chris will be gracing our walls with a piece that people will come miles to see—destination mural."

Check back here because Chris will be posting mural updates as the design progresses.  This is just a tiny sampling of the hundreds of drawings he is doing to design the mural and tell Hallowell's story.

    Help Make It Happen!

    To create the mural is months of work.  Chris, the painter one, is working now and will be over the winter for the planned unveiling of the mural in June 2019. 

    What your money pays for:

    • $480 - Rolls of 60 inch x 6 yards at $40/roll (needed approx. 12 rolls Polytab 20r #320)
    • $1700+ - Paint - Golden Acrylics (12 color palette in 32 oz tubs @ approx. $70-100 per tub)
    • $230- Brushes (wall brushes and detail--3 inch badger to ½ flats plus rollers)
    • $550 - Wall/mural adhesive and final varnish, (approximately 4 gallons of each)
    • $1700 - Rental of scaffolding or hydraulic boom “man lift” for final week mural installation (1300 per week + approx. 400 delivery and pickup.)
    • Approximately $900 for models for various poses in mural, and assistants for prep work and mural installation
    • $6860 total for supplies, hired hands and equipment.

    Plus 6 months work by the artist.  Murals are huge undertakings.  With your help here, grants and other sponsors we are hoping to raise at least $28,000 to buy supplies and to keep Chris working to get this done by June 2019.  Thanks for anything you can do.  If we can get 800 contributions of $35, we can get it done in true crowd funding classic form.  Tell a friend.  

    Keep the artist Fed!

    Importantly your money will keep Chris painting on our mural—rather than working on someone else's project, if he needs to pay his bills this winter. 

    If we can keep him fed, he can keep painting on our mural! 

    This is a pretty good mural deal for us in Hallowell.   So you can contribute here to keep him fed.  Wow, cool, kinda like an Art Zoo.   Feed the Artist!

    What else is Happening

    Chris will be hosting a some open studio days for Hall-Dale and UMA art students to stop by and learn about mural processes and techniques.  Chris feels it is very important for experienced artists to pass on skills to the next generations—or else the skill get lost.

    And he will have periodic open studio days for Hallowellians to see how the mural is progressing.

    Some Mural Thank You Perks!

    When you contribute to help make this major art piece happen, we have lots of great perks by way of thank you's.

    • $23 - a signed fine art thank you card. 
    • $195 - a signed fine art giclée print of the final mural. Ready to frame.
    • Lots of cool hand painted shirts and hats...hand painted by Chris and Jen.
    • Chris will be offering many of the beautiful drawings and studies for the mural.  One of a kind original art.
    • Or for $1000 your name or business name can be included in the mural, 
    • We are coming up with new perks all the time, so check back.

    How's it done?

    Murals are months of work.  Chris and Sam started research months ago, figuring out what parts of our history should be included.  Sam is finding tons of reference photos for Chris to work from.  

    Chris develops a mural by doing hundreds of drawings of parts of the mural, individual figures as well as overall design ideas.  The idea develops in the sketch pad over months of refinement.

    Next Chris starts figuring out the palette, the color and design by painting "color studies" of the mural parts.

    After months, once the design is fully refined, Chris does a scale version of the mural, a small painting of the mural, finished in every detail.  This smaller version ensures that all the parts work together to produce a beautiful, cohesive whole.

    Then Chris uses this scale version to enlarge it onto the full canvas.  This enlargement is sometimes done with the traditional grid enlargement method used by muralists for centuries.  

    Then Chris jumps into the months of painting the actual mural canvas.  Months of work with large brushes, buckets of paint, scaffolding, ladders...lots of work.  Physically taxing work.

    Then finally, when complete, the mural is installed on the wall.  We'll be documenting this entire process in a book, The Making of a Mural,  which is one of our fun donor perks.

    Why a Mural?

    "Why not?" sayeth the artist.   Okay, for the rest of us..why?  Well, murals are beautiful, and stunning additions to city walls.  The murals in Philadelphia and LA are destinations.  They anchor neighborhoods and make a splash.  And Chris states emphatically, "This mural will be spectacular!, bringing people from miles around."  It will add value to our city, our quality of life, and our standing as a unique and wonderful place to be.  

    Chris has painted public murals in many Maine cities. 

    • Augusta, Kennebec,  at the Capital Judicial Center, a major Percent for Art commission 
    • Brunswick, The Dance of Two Cultures mural commissioned by Brunswick Trinidad Sister City Assocaition.
    • Bath, Spirit of Bath, Commissioned by Main Street Bath, for the City of Bath.
    • Hallowell, The Teacher's Attic, a Percent for Art Mural for Hall Dale Elementary school.
    • Numerous private murals, several in Hallowell.
    •  Two major murals headed for Washington DC when they are completed in January.
    • Chris paints big.  He is super busy and we are lucky to be able to grab him to paint our City's story in a glorious way.  See more at: christophercart.com

    Risks & Challenges

    Really, the only serious problem would be if we can't keep Chris working on our mural, because this would leave us with a partially finished mural next June.  It needs to be finished to be installed. 

    Chris, the painter one, loves to paint and works his butt off, but he needs to eat, so the risk for our mural is under-funding, forcing him to do other work to pay bills and keep the bailiff away—leaving the mural sitting idle and undone.  Let's not let that happen.   

    Okay, well, there are other risks...if Chris continues to leave his coffee on his paint table he risks drinking blue coffee...but, well, we voted and that is a risk worth taking in the cause of a glorious mural.

    Our Mural Team

    We are the mural committee, well, really more of a mural gang, trading ideas via email and downtown over good beverages.  The two Chris's started this project—constantly looking for great new things for our town.

    Chris Vallee | the man with the wall

    And the first to think of the mural idea.  Never a shortage of ideas or goodwill for that matter. Also, the other Chris's new mural agent.

     

     Chris Cart | the mural artist, the guy with the brushes

    He has murals around the state--and it is high time we had one to celebrate our very own Hallowell. See more work at christophercart.com

     

     Jen Cart  | mural assistant extraordinaire

    Super talented, Jen is always on board for big mural projects, for whatever and whenever a second pair of hands is needed. 

     

    Deb Fahy | Director, The Harlow,

    Art mural consultant and general she-gets-it-done-when-you-need-it-done type help.  

     

    Sam Webber  | Hallowell Historian

    Hallowell's beloved historian--this guy knows everything. Sam has an endless knowledge and supply of images of old Hallowell.

     

    Nate Rudy | Hallowell City Manager,
    A fund of knowledge about city stuff, fundraising, art, you name it.  A great Hallowell asset and passionate about art.

     

     

    A great team for a great mural headed for a wall near you in June of 2019.

     

    Other Ways You Can Help

    • Spread the word to make this happen.
    • Share your thoughts what you think should be included in the mural to tell Hallowell's story.

    Watch for special dates, like Chris's open studio days when you can see the mural progress in person.  Also, follow progress on Facebook and Chris's website.  See you at the unveiling.

Risks & Challenges
Really, the only serious problem would be if we can't keep Chris working on our mural, because this would leave us with a partially finished mural next June.  It needs to be finished to be installed. 
Chris, the painter one, loves to paint and works his butt off, but he needs to eat, so the risk for our mural is under-funding, forcing him to do other work to pay bills and keep the bailiff away—leaving the mural sitting idle and undone.  Let's not let that happen.   Okay, well, there are other risks...if Chris continues to leave his coffee on his paint table he risks drinking blue coffee...but, well, we voted and that is a risk worth taking in the cause of a glorious mural.
Our Mural Team
We are the mural committee, well, really more of a mural gang, trading ideas via email and downtown over good beverages.  The two Chris's started this project—constantly looking for great new things for our town.

Chris Vallee  | the man with the wall
And the first to think of the mural idea.  Never a shortage of ideas or goodwill for that matter. Also, the other Chris's new mural agent.
 

 Chris Cart | the mural artist, the guy with the brushes
He has murals around the state--and it is high time we had one to celebrate our very own Hallowell. See more work at christophercart.com
 

 Jen Cart  | mural assistant extraordinaire
Super talented, Jen is always on board for big mural projects, for whatever and whenever a second pair of hands is needed. 
 

Deb Fahy | Director, The Harlow,
Art mural consultant and general she-gets-it-done-when-you-need-it-done type help.  
 

Sam Webber  | Hallowell HistorianHallowell's beloved historian--this guy knows everything. Sam has an endless knowledge and supply of images of old Hallowell. 

Nate Rudy  | Hallowell City Manager,A fund of knowledge about city stuff, fundraising, art, you name it.  A great Hallowell asset and passionate about art.
 
 
A great team for a great mural headed for a wall near you in June of 2019.
 


Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word to make this happen.
Share your thoughts what you think should be included in the mural to tell Hallowell's story.

Watch for special dates, like Chris's open studio days when you can see the mural progress in person.  Also, follow progress on Facebook and Chris's website.  See you at the unveiling.

story:
hi, world

my name is

  • jah (b. justin alexander hager)
    • justice (preferred name)

i love art, as i'm sure do you

the sense of the sublime, the uncanny, the abject,
but also something new in the world that didn't exist before,
a new way of communicating, thinking, 
a new lens.

 

peripheral forms gets eyes to art

and ears, feelings, minds, hearts, etc.

what we love most about operating as a platform for digital art is the number of eyes on the art that one can get on the art with very limited resources.

peripheral forms operates off of hand-me down equipment, a shoestring budget and my labor which i give freely because i believe in getting eyes on art more.

paying artists

we're sick, as we're sure you are, of asking artists to donate their labor, because we don't have the resources to pay them, which is part of the reason that we are launching this, our first fundraiser.

ads are art

and all displays of art are ads for the artists. social media provides an awesome opportunity with which to both disrupt the commercial aspect of social media with an aesthetic experience that critiques it but also to expose people to the brand of artists. we will use $$$ from this fundraiser also on ads for social media.

we are asking for $1,500

this goes to 4 things

  1. paying artists
  2. promoting artists
  3. compensating me for my labor
  4. hosting fees

...in that order.

this will fund.................................

Idyllic

a year of social media residencies by
Garrett Lynch, Joas-Sebastian Nebe, Hana Pera Aoake, Kaspar Ravel ░▒▓, Anneli Goeller, Alex Hovet, stephen nachtigall , Moira Ness, Kevin Brophy, Liam Herne, Chris Miller, Vishal Kumaraswamy, Julia del Rio and Guillem Sarria Verdu, Anna Ladd, Marie Muzerelle and Louis Frehring.

culminating in a 2019 publication

we intend to collect the work created as part of these residencies in a 2019 publication. 

Real Virtuality: The Networked art of Garrett Lynch

Garrett Lynch (IRL) is an artist, lecturer, curator and theorist. His work deals with networks (in their most open sense) within an artistic context; the spaces between artist, artworks and audience as a means, site and context for artistic initiation, creation and discourse. Recently most active in live performance Garrett’s networked practice spans online art, installation, performance and writing.

We will be presenting a retrospective of Garrett's work in combination with his social media residency on the web, as well as launching a pop-up exhibition.

superchambers

a new web-based work by Kello Goeller

in the words of the artist:
'superchambers' ~~ really giant scrollable images in website format (or which I might print onto fuzzy tapestries) which explore queerness and mental health struggle thru endless iterative digiworld cut&paste; mirroring the overwhelming construction of the human world around us.

Orchid

new work from Anneli Goeller

in the words of the artist:
There is a viscous fusion of truth and falsehood on the Internet; particularly concerning the way social media enables us to perform our identity. Authenticity is impossible when we have complete control over what is shared and what remains unseen. The performance of the self becomes dominant over the authentic self, a curated fiction blends into truth. This act of performance is rarely questioned, as we consume each other’s media on social networks and thus contribute to a collective obscurity of reality.

In order to explore the idea of the artificial self, this work is manifested as a 3D modeled digital avatar named Orchid who stems from my own, corporeal presence. This avatar is entirely artificial but mimics the strategies we use in media, specifically social media, to perform a version of ourselves for the viewing pleasure of others. As a way of taking ownership over my complicity in this cycle, I have taken this performance to a more extreme extent: I have formed a new identity through which to perform. In conceiving of digital space as queer space, Orchid and I exist as two separate entities. Orchid’s persona is based on mine but is autonomous, even as it is under my authority in my role as the administrator, behind the screen. Under the handle @digitalqueer Orchid can communicate with the corporeal world from within their digital one.

Orchid will be in residence on Instagam and appear in a web-based exhibition with superchambers

 

...and wait there's more..........................

 

a wiki of art tumblrs

 

a new group exhibtion:
Cyborgs: Trangressed Boundaries, Potent Fusions, and Dangerous Possibilities

!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
 

we've spent the last two years putting on group shows and presenting internet based work to the world, and we're excited to launch exciting new work into the world in 2018. your contribution to this campaign will make help make it possible for these artists to be seen and compensate them for the vision they bring to the world.

even if you can't participate financially, plz share this widely and encourage others to help!

 

!!!!THANK YOU!!!!

!!!!THANK YOU!!!!

!!!!THANK YOU!!!!

!!!!THANK YOU!!!!

!!!!THANK YOU!!!!

!!!!THANK YOU!!!!

story:
About Sinister Creature Con

"If you’ve ever found yourself marveling at the wonderfully terrifying creatures, demons and monsters in your favorite horror films, you can’t miss this event,” says Tim Meunier, Convention Founder & Director.  “We’ve gathered some of the most talented and creative CG artists, special makeup effects artists and sculptors. Their unflinching attention to detail often goes underappreciated—but in truth, horror just wouldn’t be the same without their unique talents. That is exactly why we developed Sinister Creature Con—to celebrate those responsible for our best nightmares and pull them from behind the curtain into the spotlight.”

Sinister Creature Con is a bi-annual horror convention that provides an experience unlike any other. Each June and October we celebrate past and present—from the nostalgic to the contemporary—and have a little something for every horror artist and fan. Its purpose is to serve and promote the art as well as horror genre artists that have given us wonderfully terrifying creatures like Frankenstein, Freddie Krueger, The Shape, Chucky and Jigsaw. We invite you to come, be inspired, create and scare us.

What We Need & What You Get

  • We seek a minimum of 5K.  This is a base amount that will assist us upgrade our logistics.  
  • Our goal is to purchase our own in house PA, microphones, and projection for the Sinister Creature Con Film Festival, a brand new segment to be added to Sinister Creature Con Fall 2018 at no extra cost to patrons.  As producers of the Sacramento Horror Film Festival and The Love Horror Short Film Festival, we feel strongly about our ability to curate a quality program to our convention crowd. Presentation and exhibition quality is important to us and thus we need a helping hand in order to procure equipment.
  • Additional funding will be sought to defray the overwhelming costs producing an event such as Sinister Creature Con.  Defraying costs keep our ticketing costs for adults low and free for children under the age of 10.  In a world of inflated corporate convention pricing, we want to keep our show affordable to all.
  • Funds will also be allocated to assist bringing in the bigger genre celebrity names our patrons have been asking us to book since our inception.
  • Our perks are 2nd to none compared to other festivals looking for funding on Indiegogo.

The Impact

  • In 3 years we have produced 5 successful horror conventions in Northern California.  Additionally, Love Horror Events brought the Rocky Horror Picture Show back to life in Sacramento and has entertained Sacramento over 12 years with the Sacramento Horror Film Festival.  On July 14th, we celebrate 5 years of The Love Horror Short Film Festival.  We have hosted Emmy Award Winners, Academy Award Winners, SAG Award Winners, and MTV Award Winners.  We have not only entertained Northern California for over 12 years but we have in turn created an inclusive, safe culture for all to participate in.  We are female centric, pro LGBTQ, and 100% believe in supporting artists of all walks of life.  

Risks & Challenges

We would love to be able to fund this effort in house with our own organic growth.  However, shows this size are expensive even on the base level.  Film patrons have been demanding a film festival since year one and their voices have been heard.  We wish to deliver.  However the cost involved with renting a full system is far from ideal.  Purchasing equipment in house will ensure we will not have to rely on 3rd parties and it will also ensure we will not have to raise ticket pricing in order to enhance the convention going experience.  We believe Sinister Creature Con is important to Northern California and keeping an affordable ticket price to patrons and their families is of paramount importance.

 

If you can't contribute, please consider sharing this campaign with your network.  Thank you, and LOVE HORROR!

#sinistercreaturecon

story:
Dream Come True

My name is Sandra Beaulieu, I started drawing and riding horses when I was 7 years old. After twenty years of diligent practice in both areas I was inspired to combine them together! Art on Horseback was born!

Rovandio is a 17 year old Andalusian/Lipizzan gelding that I have known since he was born. He is truly a special horse, intelligent with a heart of gold. He has become a solid performance partner and the only horse I have ever painted from horseback. 

To perform at the World Equestrian Games is a dream come true! Amazing horses and riders are flying in from all over the world, similar to the Olympic Games. The Equus Film Festival asked us to perform under their banner since I have a video entered into the festival (featured video above).

However, we just found out the great news and putting the plans together is hectic and overwhelming. The costs are adding up quickly and I am determined to get there...hopefully with your help and support!

What We Need 

Here is an approximate break down of the costs for an event of this magnitude. 

  • Shipping the Horses $2,000+
  • Gas/Travel/Tolls $800+
  • Rent a U-Haul Trailer for Art Supplies/Equipment $1,000+
  • Vet Expenses (required tests, micro-chips, coggins, health certificates, etc) $400
  • Board at a local farm during the event $1,000+
  • Lodging during the duration $1,000+
  • Event tickets $125
  • Costume Pieces $250+
  • Marketing Banner/Handouts/Postcards $300+

Amazing Perks!

It's a lot more fun to donate money when you can be involved and have something fun to show for it!

Backstage Pass $25 
Gain access to a private Facebook group for behind the scenes access before and during the World Equestrian Games. 

Baseball Cap $65
Share your support by wearing this comfortable baseball cap. Features the Art on Horseback logo embroidered on the front. Comes in White and Black, your choice. Also includes Backstage Pass.

Canvas Tote Bag $65
Proudly use this Art on Horseback bag at the barn, on the town, and at horse shows. Versatile and fun! Has two handles and a zippered pocket. Comes in black and pink! Limited quantities available. Also includes Backstage Pass.

Zip-Up Polo Shirt $85
Let's be twinsies! This is the shirt that my team and I will be wearing at WEG. This lightweight, mesh fabric that will be perfect for the warmer temps. Comes in pink and black! I want to make sure that we stand out! Features my Art on Horseback logo on the front and back. Also includes Backstage Pass.

Limited Edition Print $100
Choose between two available prints...these are also available on my website but if you purchase through this campaign it will count towards the overall total. Just specify in your order whether you would like the "Dance of Tok" or "Guerison Cheval D'Amore". Click here to view the prints. Also includes Backstage Pass.

All the Swag! $250
You will get a hat, a bag, and a shirt! Your choice of colors/sizes. Also includes the Backstage Pass.

Private Art Performance $750
Plan a private party with a group of your friends to watch Rovandio and I create a painting! Includes wine and light refreshments. Up close and personal! Times will be scheduled between October 2018 - May 2019 in Tallahassee, FL. Send me a message if you have additional questions about travel and scheduling. Also includes Backstage Pass, a hat, a bag, and a shirt.

Custom Art on Horseback Painting $2,700
​Plan a private party with a group of friends to watch Sandra and Rovandio PAINT YOUR CUSTOM MASTERPIECE! You may choose the style and color scheme to match your interior space. Includes wine and light refreshments. Times will be scheduled between October 2018 - May 2019 in Tallahassee, FL. Send me a message if you have additional questions about travel and scheduling. Also includes Backstage Pass, a hat, a bag, and a shirt.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to help financially:

  • Please use your social influence and share this campaign to help us reach our goal.
  • Watch and share our video that was entered into the Equus Film Festival. Click here.
  • Follow and share our Facebook page at: https://www.facebook.com/ArtonHorseback/
  • Follow and share the Equus Film Festival Facebook page at: https://www.facebook.com/EquusFilmFestival/

Thank you so much! I appreciate everything! Even if you just took the time to watch our videos and learn more about our story I am very thankful!

story:
About me

I am a visual artist with a background in science and more latterly, landscape oil painting. I am approaching the end of my sixth decade and want to step outside the comforts of my daily life, face new challenges and do something meaningful.  I am absolutely delighted to have been selected for this life-changing opportunity.

I have recently completed an MA in Fine Art at the University of Brighton and during my research there, I became aware of the impact that we are having on our natural world: the changes in the Arctic are being experienced more rapidly than anywhere else in the world. 

 I have visited Iceland twice and have a strong emotional response to the sublime icy and glaciated landscape there and this inspires my paintings.  My residency in Svalbard will allow me to spend a longer period of uninterrupted time in the Arctic region and will also enable me to make contact and collobarate with artists and scientists who are researching similar themes. 

When I return I will make new work using my experiences which I will share with the public through exhibitions and also social media.  I paint in both waterbased media and oils and I also make innovative artwork using the natural processes of freezing and melting.  I hope to extend this work to include using meltwater from the glaciers during my time in Svalbard.

What I am asking for

I am looking for help with 50% of the total cost of the trip.  I have partially funded the trip through the sale of my art and now need to raise the balance to cover the remaining cost of the voyage together with flights, clothing suitable for the Arctic and art materials.

All supporters will receive a unique thank-you.  These can be seen in the perks section but will include postcards from the most northerly post office on the planet together with a special  Arctic image thank-you cards when I get back, Additionally I will be offering photographic images and unique pieces of art and paintings.  All the artwork offered is at a substantial discount as an expression of gratitude for helping me reach my goal.  Every single donation will count - aside from travel costs I will be putting donations towards the cost of woolly socks or underwear or a tube of mineral watercolour pigment and other art materials.  The first 10 people to donate will receive an extra thank-you suprise in the form of a unique piece of artwork from my existing collection. 

The Impact

The project is important to me in terms of allowing me to visit a remote and very special environment and I hope to use the experience to make work that communicates the unique beauty and fragility of the Arctic region.  In the current political environment it is more important than ever before that we recognise the facts of what is happening on our planet.  The Arctic plays a crucial part in global weather patterns generating ocean currents that act to cool the world.  The sea ice too acts as a mirror reflecting back rays from the sun.  The loss of sea ice that is happening now is an urgent signal that we are profoundly affecting the earth's systems.  I hope to interact with scientists during the voyage to deepen my understanding of climate change and hence develop my artwork further.  The Arctic Circle residency will be an important next step in my professional development as an artist and I hope that I will be able to use my experience and the artwork that I create to engage the public in a discussion about our impact on the environment. 

Risks & Challenges

I am aware of two main risks to me personally.  Firstly I don't have good sea-legs and have never spent longer than a few hours at sea and secondly I'm not good in cold climates.   I plan to mitigate the cold with good Arctic clothing and have been advised by previous participants what to buy.  If we meet with extreme weather during the voyage I hope to remedy any sea-sicknes with acupuncture and have an acupuncturist friend who is going to teach me how to administer acupuncture myself.  I believe that my enthusiasm, excitement and joy of being in the Arctic landscape will play a large part too, in overcoming these challenges. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to help by making a donation, it would be very valuable if you can share my campaign through your social networks.  Indiegogo has a share facility too.

My Instagram feed is https://www.instagram.com/adelegibsonart/

My Facebook page is https://www.facebook.com/adelegibsonart/

I will be making a blog of my experience and will post details on my social media.
story_txt:
About me
I am a visual artist with a background in science and more latterly, landscape oil painting. I am approaching the end of my sixth decade and want to step outside the comforts of my daily life, face new challenges and do something meaningful.  I am absolutely delighted to have been selected for this life-changing opportunity.
I have recently completed an MA in Fine Art at the University of Brighton and during my research there, I became aware of the impact that we are having on our natural world: the changes in the Arctic are being experienced more rapidly than anywhere else in the world. 
 I have visited Iceland twice and have a strong emotional response to the sublime icy and glaciated landscape there and this inspires my paintings.  My residency in Svalbard will allow me to spend a longer period of uninterrupted time in the Arctic region and will also enable me to make contact and collobarate with artists and scientists who are researching similar themes. 
When I return I will make new work using my experiences which I will share with the public through exhibitions and also social media.  I paint in both waterbased media and oils and I also make innovative artwork using the natural processes of freezing and melting.  I hope to extend this work to include using meltwater from the glaciers during my time in Svalbard.
What I am asking for

I am looking for help with 50% of the total cost of the trip.  I have partially funded the trip through the sale of my art and now need to raise the balance to cover the remaining cost of the voyage together with flights, clothing suitable for the Arctic and art materials.
All supporters will receive a unique thank-you.  These can be seen in the perks section but will include postcards from the most northerly post office on the planet together with a special  Arctic image thank-you cards when I get back, Additionally I will be offering photographic images and unique pieces of art and paintings.  All the artwork offered is at a substantial discount as an expression of gratitude for helping me reach my goal.  Every single donation will count - aside from travel costs I will be putting donations towards the cost of woolly socks or underwear or a tube of mineral watercolour pigment and other art materials.  The first 10 people to donate will receive an extra thank-you suprise in the form of a unique piece of artwork from my existing collection. 

The Impact
The project is important to me in terms of allowing me to visit a remote and very special environment and I hope to use the experience to make work that communicates the unique beauty and fragility of the Arctic region.  In the current political environment it is more important than ever before that we recognise the facts of what is happening on our planet.  The Arctic plays a crucial part in global weather patterns generating ocean currents that act to cool the world.  The sea ice too acts as a mirror reflecting back rays from the sun.  The loss of sea ice that is happening now is an urgent signal that we are profoundly affecting the earth's systems.  I hope to interact with scientists during the voyage to deepen my understanding of climate change and hence develop my artwork further.  The Arctic Circle residency will be an important next step in my professional development as an artist and I hope that I will be able to use my experience and the artwork that I create to engage the public in a discussion about our impact on the environment. 

Risks & Challenges
I am aware of two main risks to me personally.  Firstly I don't have good sea-legs and have never spent longer than a few hours at sea and secondly I'm not good in cold climates.   I plan to mitigate the cold with good Arctic clothing and have been advised by previous participants what to buy.  If we meet with extreme weather during the voyage I hope to remedy any sea-sicknes with acupuncture and have an acupuncturist friend who is going to teach me how to administer acupuncture myself.  I believe that my enthusiasm, excitement and joy of being in the Arctic landscape will play a large part too, in overcoming these challenges. 
 

Other Ways You Can Help
If you are unable to help by making a donation, it would be very valuable if you can share my campaign through your social networks.  Indiegogo has a share facility too.
My Instagram feed is https://www.instagram.com/adelegibsonart/
My Facebook page is https://www.facebook.com/adelegibsonart/
I will be making a blog of my experience and will post details on my social media.

story:
THE TREE OF LIFE

The Tree of Life is a 110-foot tall art piece that activates an ancient symbol and invites you on a journey through life. It is an interactive art and architecture sculpture created for you to come play and awaken your senses. As you enter the piece, you will be among the roots where an ambisonic sound space is brought to life with captivating performances and gatherings. A 90ft tall central light and sound atrium moves you through the heart of the tree. Ascending the atrium staircase, you are embraced by the vibrations and frequencies of the seven chakras through the ambisonic surround sound. At the top, you arrive in the Temple of the Stars, a place to spend time friends contemplating the wonders of Black Rock City. The Tree of Life is your home to feel into the interactive exchange between the earth and space, nature and technology, in which both the internal journey and external expression are brought together. We invite you to be part of the team by giving life to the Tree of Life. 

 

BUILDING PROCESS

We are building this art piece through sustainable and innovative practices to live in one of the most extreme environments on Earth at Burning Man. This piece demonstrates new levels of architectural possibility and communicates the priority of sustainability. The main structure is made of Glulam, a renewable building material sustainably harvested from the forest along with recycled steel, aluminum, and fabric. Computer modeling allows us to design for extreme environments while saving time, money and minimizing risk. The computer modeling process has given us the opportunity to test every single part of the design and save time in building by optimizing the process Connecting our digitals models directly with CNC robots cuts the Glulam pieces to the perfect size and specification needed. Creating the steel connectors was an intellectually intensive process, that resulted in finding a design that allows us to optimize the installation process and reduce installation time. With our growing community we are crafting the sunrise and sunset faces that personify the Tree of Life and the fabric art that adorns the trunk and canopy. We invite you to participate and get involved in the process of creating! 

EXPERIENTIAL TECHNOLOGY  

Highlighting the experiential technology is an ambisonic surround sound system and a lighting system that mirrors the movement of people and light patterns in nature. Within the Tree of Life the sound and light atrium experience can take human consciousness from linear to spherical. 

THE INSPIRATION & MESSAGE

The Tree of Life is inspired by and in tribute to the tragedy of the Columbia Gorge fire in Oregon, followed by the North Bay and Thomas fires in California. Through the process of giving life to this piece and activating it as a portal for creativity, it is our goal to create stronger awareness and processes of action for stewarding and caring for the forests and the ecosystems that support our lives. We want to live in a world where ecosystems are valued and humans live in harmony with planet Earth. We want to bring the presence of an old growth tree to the playa as a monument to nature imbuing it with the life and magic of Black Rock City. By creating this piece we honor those beings affected by the fires and want to assist in creating a change where human relationships with the forests become stronger and fires are stewarded as a natural process of the ecosystem without harming our homes and destroying the forest canopy.

We are committed to creatively work on solutions to the challenges facing our world's natural environments.This movement does not end with this art piece, it is a beginning. We invite you to the possibility of creatively reconnecting with natural environments and become active stewards of our lands.

 

POST PLAYA LIFE

The Tree of Life will have a long life after Burning Man as a center for creativity, knowledge sharing and healing. After Burning Man we will transport the piece to its permanent location and continue to host a variety of gatherings, workshops and ceremonies. This will enhance the growth of the project into its fullest potential as an incubator for creativity. We are excited for the community that attracts and houses the Tree of Life! We are currently talking with various communities about where and how it will live after Burning Man 2018.

 

HOW YOU MAKE AN IMPACT

The Tree of Life is grateful for the seed funding for this project and receiving the Honorarium from Burning Man Arts. This is a great start for our project, however we need your support! 
Your donations and contributions will help us purchase the Gluelam and steel pieces needed and move into the construction of the main structure.

Please donate and share this campaign with your community! Stayed tuned to our updates and our growing team through our Facebook page, our website and our Instagram page.

The Tree of Life is an expression of pure love for nature and every life form that supports our aliveness, please join us in this vision!

Thank you for your support!!

 

THE TEAM

story:
About the Spa

The Spa at Lake Lahontan is a container for the breadth and depth of stories held within the Black Rock Desert -- stories of the earth, the people, the flora and fauna; of geological change and human impact. It's a place that contains mysteries and secrets and a place where time is elastic and cyclical. 

 

Spa at Lake Lahontan (in Golden Guy Alley)

This year, we're bringing a teaser of the Spa experience to Black Rock City as part of Golden Guy Alley -- a magical neighborhood of micro bars and immersive experiences that fosters community and conversation modeled after the Golden Gai district in the Shinjuku area of Tokyo. The Spa in its full glory needs time to germinate and evolve. So, we're taking a full year to develop the concept.  This campaign is for the 2019 Spa at Lake Lahontan experience in Golden Guy Alley. 

The Spa is literally immersive. It's an old west style building that echoes the Gold and Silver Rush eras of California and Nevada. Signage invites you to “soak” in the (nonexistent) bathtubs, to take in the (imaginary) vistas, to ring reception bells and wait for a vanished concierge. Enjoy a cocktail or a special Spa elixir while submerging yourself in an aural and visual adventure of the Black Rock Desert. Photographs, paintings, and curios created by a variety of artists tell a story that traverses timelines of geology, human culture, industry, flora, and fauna. A layered soundscape envelops and disorients you with flowing water and rattling pipes; oral histories of Lake Lahontan and the Western desert; sounds of the natural world; and musical delights. 

During the day, partake in a variety of Spa "treatments" while in the evening, delight in micro performances and shenanigans courtesy of the owners of the establishment and visitors alike. Don't be surprised to find a tarot card reader teaching the samba to a wanted bank robber. Or a fiddle player and a a stilt walker waxing poetic over a refreshing Lake Lahontan Gimlet. 

Be the first to get in on Spa reservations for 2020 using our special telephony device, or make a call to a long lost friend you never knew you had.  

Above all, we hope you find relaxation and solace -- with a side of slight discomfort and angst -- as you soak in a spa with no water: the Spa at Lake Lahontan (in Golden Guy Alley). 

 

What we need & What you get 

We are looking to raise $6,000 through this Indiegogo campaign to support The Spa at Lake Lahontan (in Golden Guy Alley) in 2019 and to invest in the vision for 2020. This seed funding will help us get the project off the ground and help us bring something really magical to the playa this year. The infrastructure we purchase this year will be utilized for the 2020 project.

This project is sponsored by the FLUX Foundation, a 501c3 nonprofit based in Oakland, CA. All donations to this campaign are tax deductible to the extent allowed by law. 

Here's where the money will go: 

Our budget: $7,200 + 10% contingency = $8000

  • $2200 materials, consumables, and wall treatments
  • $1000 transportation 
  • $250 fuel for power
  • $500 tiny art grants (to collaborating artists)
  • $350 sound 
  • $300 lighting
  • $750 bar supplies, cocktails + elixirs
  • $1000 interior design + furniture
  • $350 insurance
  • $500 fundraising gifts

Our gifts

  • Get our amazing logo on a variety of fun Spa souvenir items
  • Relax with lovely bath and body products created by Sequoia Soaps, a proudly indigenous woman owned and operated small business
  • Enjoy a bottle of one of our bespoke elixirs (pick available on playa)
  • Own a print of a Spa at Lake Lahontan poster designed by our team
  • Wear a a limited edition cutthroat trout pin, official mascot of The Spa 

 

Why support the Spa?

By contributing to this funding campaign, you are supporting two important things:

  1. A valuable contribution to the spectacular Golden Guy Alley community that furthers their mission and delight participants; and
  2. The exploration of this idea to allow it take root and grow over time. 

2019 is about exploring possibilities -- making connections with people and places in the desert, creating artwork and soundscapes that tell stories, and testing out ideas for experiences and engagement. We aim to bring this magic in small scale to our space in Golden Guy. 

We're passionate about creating remarkable moments of connection between people and inspiring joy through the immersive artworks we design and build. We're also deeply committed to telling stories of place and history and creating situations that invite people to explore their relationship to their environment, built and natural, and to each other. 

 

Who we are

The Spa at Lake Lahontan is a project created by Catie Magee and Jennifer Blakeslee and designed by Jackie Scott. It's sponsored by the FLUX Foundation, a 501c3 nonprofit organization based in Oakland, CA. Many of us have been part of FLUX since its inception in 2010 with the Temple of FLUX, and others are from a wide range of art collectives.

We have been building interactive experiences together for more than a decade, but this is our first deep storytelling experience. We are excited for the challenge of weaving a visual, aural, and experiential adventure through telling the story of the Black Rock Desert.

We have assembled a team of set designers, sound artists, visual and graphic designers, food and cocktail creators, and makers of all kinds to bring this vision to life. We are committed to working together to craft a truly remarkable, immersive, and layered experience in The Spa that will transport participants to another place and time and bring them closer to understanding the breadth and depth of the desert's life. 

 

How you can help

  • Make a contribution to this campaign. All donations are tax deductible to the extent permitted by law. (Note that you may only deduct the amount of your donation less the value of the gift you receive.) 
  • Get the word out! Share our campaign on social media.

story:
I'm Gail Mitchell...a visual artist in Brooklyn, NY, who is excited to have been selected for The Arctic Circle Residency this fall. It is a great honor and opportunity to be included on this journey with other artists, writers, scientists and creators aboard the Tall Ship Antigua.

http://thearcticcircle.org/participants/

Many different experiences have led me on this path...including: a three-week long Polish cargo ship journey in January of 1996; a lifelong obsession with cold climates; and a serious habit of collecting things from shorelines. My artworks are often comprised of found objects and wax rubbings of surface textures. On this trip we will be exploring the Arctic Circle, making daily landings, where I have learned we will come across bits of flotsam, jetsam and everyday discards. I plan to create an "awareness armada" built from sea finds, wax rubbings and coupled with driftwood that has washed ashore on the North Fork of Long Island. I chose local driftwood as the method of flotation in part to literally connect these two worlds; it is also a nod to the fact that trees are a renewable resource that undoubtedly plays a major part in helping combat climate change. This flotilla of assemblages will be to bring awareness to the fact that even what we think of as pristine and far away glacial waters, have in fact been impacted by everyone. My plan is to have these art vessels float, albeit not with the intent to return to the oceans, but simply to serve as ambassadors representing from whence they came. These transformed pieces of history enjoin their pasts with the present, unabashedly forcing the viewer to see them anew...still afloat but safely on display.

In addition to the vessel building, I will be photographing, drawing, writing, sound recording, etc. All of these activities will undoubtedly provide material and experience to fuel many future artworks and endeavors.

I would love to have your support! My funding goal is only a portion of the total trip cost. It is an awkward thing to ask for financial help but it is also a way for me to more personally share my trip with everyone. Those of you who know me, have heard many tales of my former adventures...I anticipate that this trip will be the most life changing one yet. Thank you in advance for considering supporting me in this latest embarkment.

some more examples of my photography and several artworks:

Polish cargo ship 1996

 

docked ship Reykjavik, Iceland

 

ferry from Lofoten to Bodo. Norway

 

"structured handful"  glass, bone, plastic, x-ray, paint, wire, metal sign letter, etc.   33 x 32 x 5"

 

"couped pattern"  paper clothes patterns, architectural plans, ship rope, paint, etc. 32 x 39"

 

"friendship trap no.872"  plastic beach finds, metal, asphalt, paint, string, etc.  9 x 6 x 1.5"

 

"wired fragments"  mixed media: wire, brass, string, glass, aluminum, paper  12 x 3.5"

 

"indigo penmanship" mixed media: metal, paint, graphite on indigo dyed canvas

story:
What is the Talking Walls Mural Festival?

TALKING WALLS strives to show the world in a highly visible way that Charlotte is a creative hub and a city that supports and welcomes artistic influencers. We hate beige, boring, and bland walls. We want to push the vibrancy of Charlotte through beautiful works of mural art.

Talking walls will:

  • Curate 15+ new public outdoor murals in Charlotte, adding to the 18 murals we put up in 2018.
  • Engage 15+ local, national, and international artists
  • Program several days worth of family friendly art focused events & night parties
  • Execute all of this over the course of one week in October (October 16th - 19th)

 

What We Need 

Simply put, we need funding to pull off this festival. If you donate, this is where your dollars are going:

  • We provide each artist a stipend for their time and energy
  • We provide all the paint for the artists
  • We provide all the hydraulic lifts and equipment for artists
  • We provide hotels, airfare, and travel accommodations for artists
  • We provide food and drinks for the artists while they are in town


In addition, the production costs to pull this off add up quickly: runners, transportation, photographers, videographers, creative design, signage, insurance, events, security, storage, etc.

The only area where your dollars don't go is to the leadership of Talking Walls. We are completely and 100% driven by a small group of community volunteers and we do not take $1 from this festival (in fact many of us donate our own money to help pull this thing off).

 

The Impact

When the festival is complete Charlotte will be the home to 15+ highly visible and vibrant massive works of mural art. 

  • Our goal is to paint in as many new locations as possible each year to increase the total # of mural works Charlotte has to offer, thereby increasing the vibrancy of the city.
  • Murals are a great way to show the public that Charlotte is open for business and supports local art.
  • Murals raise the flag to other artists that Charlotte supports their arts community.
  • You are investing in your city, your landscape, your culture, and your community.
  • We are moving art out of the museums and into the streets. Free for all to enjoy for years to come!

 

Risks & Challenges

The costs of the festival are around $80,000.

  • We are actively pitching corporate sponsors and partners, but this takes time and energy.
  • Whatever you can do to help will be massive. $25 or $100 it all goes right back into the arts community. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Get the word out about Talking Walls!
  • Share this IndieGogo campaign.
  • Share our Instagram handle: @talkingwallscharlotte
  • Visit & share our website: www.talkingwallscharlotte.com
story_txt:
What is the Talking Walls Mural Festival?
TALKING WALLS strives to show the world in a highly visible way that Charlotte is a creative hub and a city that supports and welcomes artistic influencers. We hate beige, boring, and bland walls. We want to push the vibrancy of Charlotte through beautiful works of mural art.
Talking walls will:

Curate 15+ new public outdoor murals in Charlotte, adding to the 18 murals we put up in 2018.
Engage 15+ local, national, and international artists
Program several days worth of family friendly art focused events & night parties
Execute all of this over the course of one week in October (October 16th - 19th)


 
What We Need 
Simply put, we need funding to pull off this festival. If you donate, this is where your dollars are going:

We provide each artist a stipend for their time and energy
We provide all the paint for the artists
We provide all the hydraulic lifts and equipment for artists
We provide hotels, airfare, and travel accommodations for artists
We provide food and drinks for the artists while they are in town

In addition, the production costs to pull this off add up quickly: runners, transportation, photographers, videographers, creative design, signage, insurance, events, security, storage, etc.
The only area where your dollars don't go is to the leadership of Talking Walls. We are completely and 100% driven by a small group of community volunteers and we do not take $1 from this festival (in fact many of us donate our own money to help pull this thing off).

 
The Impact
When the festival is complete Charlotte will be the home to 15+ highly visible and vibrant massive works of mural art. 

Our goal is to paint in as many new locations as possible each year to increase the total # of mural works Charlotte has to offer, thereby increasing the vibrancy of the city.
Murals are a great way to show the public that Charlotte is open for business and supports local art.
Murals raise the flag to other artists that Charlotte supports their arts community.
You are investing in your city, your landscape, your culture, and your community.
We are moving art out of the museums and into the streets. Free for all to enjoy for years to come!


 
Risks & Challenges
The costs of the festival are around $80,000.


We are actively pitching corporate sponsors and partners, but this takes time and energy.

Whatever you can do to help will be massive. $25 or $100 it all goes right back into the arts community. 


 
Other Ways You Can Help
Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

Get the word out about Talking Walls!
Share this IndieGogo campaign.
Share our Instagram handle: @talkingwallscharlotte

Visit & share our website: www.talkingwallscharlotte.com

story:
Parallel Self Embraced is an upcoming art installation for Burning Man 2021. Awarded an Honoraria for Burning Man 2020, the piece was postponed due to the Covid-19 pandemic. Work never stopped however, and now the piece is in need of some starter funds to begin the bulk material producing and manufacturing necessary to make the piece a reality.

Piece Concept:

In brief: We live in tumultuous and divided times. Our relationship to each other today is often one of disagreement, strife, and tribal mentality. Parallel Self Embraced presents an alternative - encouraging a coming together interpersonally. The piece forms a sort of abstract mirror. Identical on either side, participants step up to it and see the person across from them. Within an infinite number of universes, in an infinite number of timelines, all events are possible, and in infinity, within some space and some time, you are me and I am you. Parallel Self Embraced thus functions as a looking glass through which to see a partner, a friend, even just a stranger, as a reflection of the self that could be, and the beauty inherent to the person traveling in a world parallel to yourself.

Physical description: Twin 12' by 12' square panels made of welded pipe and metal bars stand parallel, a foot apart, with wooden stairs leading up to the center of each panel on either side. Lines of the structure radiate from the outside of the square inward toward human-shaped negative spaces. Parallel Self Embraced is an outdoor installation. By day the piece appears as an abstract dark metal sculpture with lines radiating out. By night, LED pixels along the radiating lines light up. When a person enters either of the human shaped negative spaces, they trip a variety of interdependent Arduino sensors (eg. proximity sensor, photoresistor tripwire, pressure sensor, etc.) that connect to the LED strands and audio processors. Discreet speakers provide a daytime interaction element and lie beneath the stairs of either side.

Who We Are:

I'm lead artist Matthew Pagoaga. I brought 'Cirrus - The musical weather robotic soloist' to Burning Man 2018. You might have met him! Cirrus sang over 5,000 songs a day at Burning Man 2018 based on live weather data for a given zip code. Our team for that work(and Parallel Self Embraced) is made up of members of theme camp, Shibumi (est. 2010.) If you've been in the 7:30 sector of Burning mans past, you might have had a cocktail at our bar, made use of our confession booth, heard our annual story time morning, or just gotten down to Wu-Tang Wednesday. 

What We Need & What You Get:

We're offering rewards for various levels of donation, but, in truth, need anything we can get:

  • We need starter funds to begin the purchasing and manufacturing of the piece. This includes buying the LED, drivers, metal, and sensors for the project. 
  • Any amount donated will support the construction of this piece.
  • Donators will be listed as contributors the piece and thanked in materials supporting the work, and on my personal website. 
  • Stickers, pins, and pendants are also rewards for the various donation levels! 

The Impact:

Parallel Self Embraced is situated to emerge from one of the strangest chapters of our modern history. We've conducted a fast of immediacy, intimacy, and connection in this pandemic. I believe we're going to reemerge communicating entirely different -- reevaluating our connections to each other both immediate and distanced. Parallel Self Embraced is thus able to serve as a meeting point for the 'after' of this drought, encouraging a coming together both physically and interpersonally. I believe it will be a valuable work, particularly in post pandemic placement.

Risks & Challenges:

No project is without risk. We don't know where this pandemic will go, and when we'll be free to emerge and embrace. That said, we are committed to bringing this piece to full reality in the aftermath of everything, whenever that may be. Your donation will feed a full size installation. Guaranteed.

Other Ways You Can Help:

We understand that these are difficult times. Excess funds to donate to art projects are often just not there. We're still soliciting collaborators and crew for the piece. If you have a valuable skillset that you think would aid this piece, we'd love to hear from you. You may be invited to join the crew and attend Burning Man 2021 with us!

story:
Tottering Biped Theatre (TBT) is a full charity status organization founded in 2009 as a social justice inspired theatre company. Our performances have addressed poverty, Israeli-Palestinian relations, same sex marriage, violence against women, and mental health.

Since 2016, Tottering Biped Theatre has presented our original takes on Shakespeare at the beautiful Rock Gardens of the Royal Botanical Gardens. Our team descended on the Gardens each August to present the contemporary issues we care about with flair to the words of the immortal Bard, marrying the traditional with the issues of today to inspire reflection, new perspectives, and change.

Unfortunately, the RBG has decided not to present our work again after 4 years of collaboration and despite having our largest audience yet in 2019. So we’re working to save 'Shakespeare at the Rock' and transform it into...'Shakespeare at the Castle' – Dundurn Castle in Hamilton, Ontario.

This change is exciting. This shift will radically improve our accessibility in 3 ways:

1. We have always wanted to offer ‘Pay-What-You-Can’ tickets, but the RBG dictated ticket prices, making this impossible. With Shakespeare at the Castle, we will finally be able to make all tickets ‘Pay-What-You-Can’ so that more people can get in and get their Shakespeare on!

2. We will also now be much closer to downtown Hamilton at a location that is much more accessible by public transportation, again allowing more people to enjoy our shows and receive the benefits of the arts.

3. We will also now have more artistic control over the work and be able to fully embrace our own social justice aesthetic while pursuing our goal of getting living wages into the hands of emerging professional artists in our area.

Tax donations over $200 can request donation receipts for income tax purposes. 

 

What We Need & What You Get

If we can raise the money to pay our artists in advance this year, we can save the money we earn in ticket sales and put that towards next year’s budget. So, if we can get this money together one time, we will be able to sustainably carry on this project in subsequent seasons.

Our goal is to make this a legacy series for Hamilton and the surrounding region, and this is the make or break year that will decide if that happens.

Please consider contributing to this fantastic project!

Patron Sponsor ($100-$499):

Recognition by name on our website and in our Shakespeare at the Castle programs.

Bronze Sponsor ($500-$999):

Above benefits + A poster signed by the cast and a full cast/crew "Thank You" photo

Silver Sponsor ($1K -$2.4K):

Above benefits + Pair of tickets for our dress rehearsal and Q&A talkback and photo op with the cast and director of Shakespeare at the Castle.

Gold Sponsor ($2.5K-$4.9K):

All above benefits + 

- If you want to be the slick silent partner type, you get a coffee with one of our cast members before the show to learn about their experience and ask any questions you want!

OR

- If you want to shout it out, a 3-foot sign with your name or company name/logo will be displayed at the Dundurn Castle performances throughout the run + a quarter-page ad or your personal message/dedication in our program.

Platinum Sponsor ($5K-$9.9K):

All above benefits +

- If you want to be the slick silent partner type, dinner with one of our actors to learn about what they are going through in preparation for the role you’ve enabled and to ask any questions you would like!

OR

- If you want to shout it out, a 5-foot sign with your name or company name/logo will be displayed at the Dundurn Castle performances throughout the run + a half-page ad or your personal message/dedication in our program.

Diamond Sponsor ($10K+):

All above benefits +

- Program and website recognition as the Lead Supporter of Shakespeare at the Castle

- A full page ad or your personal message/dedication in our program

- Dinner with the Artistic Director before rehearsals begin

 

The Impact

Hamilton has little to no opportunities for paid work in Theatre. That means that all our emerging professionals move away in order to begin their careers. This is why our series is so vital - we are a key piece in changing that system and making a lifestyle for professional theatre artists in Hamilton possible, thereby also keeping invaluable arts experiences available to the community of this great city. 

 

One time fundraising, permanent impact. If we are able to raise this money, this year then all of this summer's ticket income will become next year's budget. It will all pay forward - and create sustainable income for this series moving ahead. 

 

We have been producing this work every summer since 2016. We have been attracting about 2000 people each summer with our work. We know how to do it. We just need this help to break into our own new space - and become a legacy for Hamilton Theatre!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We need all the help we can get to spread word about this campaign and the show itself once it launches. Sharing this information and encouraging people to come is the best marketing that money can't even buy. Pushing this out there in whatever way you can will make all the difference to us. Thank you in advance from the bottom of our hearts!
